episodes.title: 35: Don’t Make Your Landlord Rich
episodes.description: If you’re starting a new business, you need to keep costs low – so renting is the way to go, right? I say no! I’ll tell you why you should scrape together the cash to buy your business headquarters from the get-go.  Also, I’ll answer some more of your great questions about how to get the press to pay attention to your little mom and pop shop and what to do about a toxic work environment. Got a business question you want to ask me? Tweet it @BarbaraCorcoran and I may just answer it on a future episode! Follow Business Unusual with Barbara Corcoran on iHeartRadio, or subscribe wherever you listen to podcasts. This episode of Business Unusual with Barbara Corcoran is presented by On Deck Business Loans (http://www.ondeck.com/barbara).

episodes.title: Do Things That Scale: Starting a Business That Will Take Off

podcast.title: Listen Money Matters - Free your inner financial badass. All the stuff you should know about personal finance.
podcast.publisher: ListenMoneyMatters.com | Andrew Fiebert and Matt Giovanisci

episodes.description:
There are only so many hours in a day so you need to build a business that can grow while you’re sleeping, on vacation, or working on your next business. You have to do things that scale when starting a business that will take off. While we are discussing scaling a business, there are plenty of other areas of life that you can scale including investing and video games. To scale a business means to create a system, product, or service that can generate more money through some resource that isn’t your time. Scale is a concept that is meant to support infinite growth. When starting a business, you want to find ways to apply your time and money that are scalable and to shift your focus from things with a hard maximum return to things that have the potential to be infinitely scalable.

 

Full Article Here

Show Notes

Board Meeting: A coffee flavored brown ale.

Tool Box: All the best stuff to manage your money.

Do Things That Don't Scale: The essay Andrew mentioned by Paul Graham.
